issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Signifies completion of tasks, info requests, etc.
resolution.name: Completed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: An example of this is the disk read bytes where there can be megs worth of data transferred in the period but the value shows in bytes. Screenshot attached.
fields.summary: For monitoring tiles, we should collapse units to Mb and Gb where possible

comments.body: [~viglesias], this sounds good. We use the same units AWS does initially, but I agree, collapsing makes sense. Which ones, based on your experience, should be collapsed, and into what units? Thanks!
we can be smart about this and don't need input, Vic. Will need to update tile titles too, Disk read data and Disk write data instead of Disk read bytes and Disk write bytes.
PR at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1471

[~jloza]: Note that in PR 1471 I updated the chart titles for the DiskReadBytes and DiskWriteBytes metrics to "Disk read data" and "Disk write data" as mentioned in your prior comment, and the y-axis label is set to "Kilobytes".  However, the metrics were left as DiskReadBytes and DiskWriteBytes for AWS compatibility (and since those are the standard metric names).
[~kgill] it looks like this only collapses to KB, but what about MB and GB when appropriate?
[~jloza]: I opted to only collapse to KB since we were already doing that for the Network In/Out metrics, and collapsing to KB should be adequate for usual (read: non-QA) disk read/write loads.

[~kgill] We don't know (and cannot predict, but should gracefully display) the size of customer loads, why not include the smarts to collapse to whatever is appropriate? KB, MB, GB, TB?

Should also collapse fully network in/out beyond KB (take KB out of title there too).

[~jloza]: Let's discuss this Thursday.  There are significant complications w.r.t. collapsing based on metric amounts rather than just adopting a standard "always collapse ____ metrics to KB", which is probably why AWS opts not to collapse.  Even with the ridiculously huge disk read bytes numbers in the chart screenshot uploaded by [~viglesias], collapsing to KB allows the y-axis units to display just fine (i.e. the numbers don't overlap the y-axis label).  Also, using the chart in the screenshot as an example, I wonder if a customer would prefer to see to 30204 KB rather than 30 MB.
[~kgill], OK, can wait til Thurs. Or perhaps later. I will try and get some customer feedback on this.

[~jloza]: Understood.  IMO we should merge PR 1471 for now since collapsing Disk read/write bytes to KB is so much better than not collapsing those.  And perhaps we can leave this ticket open to wait on the MB/GB collapsing feedback?

[~jloza]: I pushed commit https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/commit/4d9467a2ec81 which collapses values in the DiskReadBytes and DiskWriteBytes charts to MB when appropriate.  I've also attached before/after screenshots for the MB collapsing.
[~kgill], will it collapse to GB when that makes sense? Or TB (future proofing is awesome!)

Thanks, Kamal! In addition to previous comment, I noticed that network in and out should have KB removed from tile title and should also be collapsing as appropriate please. Also, makes sense to display 1 decimal point to the right as well, for better granularity and meaning when collapsed, agreed? IDK if you did this or not, I'd need a system generating that much data to check.

[~jloza]: I'll add NetworkIn and NetworkOut to the GB collapsing whitelist (they're currently only collapsing to KB) and will update the chart titles accordingly.

I strongly feel that collapsing to KB and MB is adequate for this ticket.  If you agree, we should probably change the title of this ticket to "For monitoring tiles, we should collapse to KB and MB where possible".  For collapsing to GB and TB, we should gather customer feedback since those seem like corner cases.

To clarify on the unit precision, we could display 2 decimal points for KB and 1 for MB, which is a trivial fix so let me know if that sounds good.

hi [~kgill], decimal points sound great, yes please.

Is it a significant amount of work to collapse to GB when needed? I would like to understand more abut why you are pushing back on that. We can (and will) get feedback from customers to verify, but we do have customers with significant data movement, and with the size of our charts it seems like the collapsed data would have better readability. I think we should do that now and change it if customers don't like it, rather than wait for more of them to ask for it and open a new ticket when we could have fixed it with this one. [~viglesias] is a legitimate cloud user and should be considered a real data point, even if just one.

[~jloza]: It isn't a significant amount of work to collapse to GB, so I'll go ahead and make those changes.  I was concerned about the performance of collapsing to MB and GB since we'll need to compute the max value of all data points for each chart that collapses the values, but if we restrict the charts that collapse to Disk read/write bytes, we should be fine.

Implemented the following changes...
- Added Network In/Out to collapse whitelist
- Update chart title for Network In/Out
- Collapse to GB where appropriate for Network In/Out and Disk read/write bytes

Note: Use 'kg-vpc-instance-2 (i-16b63ae1)' on our shared AWS account (Oregon region) to test this.  I couldn't get enough data to trigger the metrics to display in GB, but the NetworkIn is in MB and NetworkOut is in KB.

I couldn't visually check the display int eh console because the big instance had already been cleaned up and terminated in our AWS account, but I did look at the files and check the changes, and they look like they will display the correct info. That'll have to do in this case, rather than setting up a new instance and waiting for data to accumulate, since we are running out of time. 

So, ready for code review. Thanks, [~kgill] for your patience and tenacity on this one!
[~dkavanagh]: Would be nice to get PR 1471 reviewed/merged soon, esp. since it was opened almost a month ago.
It was only assigned to me on Wednesday. I'll go take a look now.
Released in 4.2
